column1: Optional: To find available meeting slots in your agenda, the virtual assistant will require access to your calendar. To allow access, you can add a link to your calendar using the web app. You can also remove access at any time. By checking "‚úì", you permit us to have read-only access to your calendar.
column2: In order to use the web application, you provide your personal information such as your name and email address. Optionally, you can also add your phone numbers and office addresses to allow the virtual assistant to schedule in-person meetings or phone calls. By checking "‚úì", you permit us to store this information and use it for scheduling appointments.
column3: Under the General Data Protection Regulation, we need your permission to store your information on our servers. You can export a copy of all your data or permanently delete it at any time from the web application. By selecting an option, you permit us to store your information.
column4: Which type of profession best describes you? This helps us relate scheduling experience with types of work.
column5: Say you had to schedule an appointment with a colleague (if you're a professional) or a professor (if you're a student). How would you do it? Select as many as you like.
column6: How frequently do you send emails, on average, on working days? This includes both work and personal emails.
column7: How frequently do you check your email, on average, on working days?
column8: What languages do you send emails in? Enter as many as you like.
column9: Do you have email notifications enabled on your phone?
column10: What service do you use for your primary email account?
column11: What do you use email for? Select as many as you like.
column12: What calendar service do you use, if any? Select as many as you like.
column13: If you had a personal assistant, would you ask them to schedule your appointments for you?
column14: Imagine that you had an AI-powered, virtual personal assistant who could set up appointments for you by finding available times in your calendar and sending emails on your behalf. Would you use this service?
column15: Say that you ask your virtual assistant to schedule an appointment with someone. For the recipient, this email would be indistinguishable from an email sent by a human assistant. Should the virtual assistant inform the recipient that it is not a human, but an AI-powered virtual assistant?
column16: Should recipients be able to unsubscribe from your assistant's emails, i.e., "opt out" of talking to an AI, and choose to only communicate with you instead?
column17: Would you like to know whether or not someone has seen an email sent by the assistant?
column18: If you have enabled email tracking, should end users know that a read receipt has been shared, i.e., a notice at the end of the email, "The sender has been notified that you've opened this email"?
column19: Apart from scheduling appointments, what else would you like your virtual assistant to do, over email? Enter as many as you like.
column20: What comes to mind when you think about EIVA (how would you describe it to a friend)?
column21: Overall experience of the web app (not the assistant)
column24: Ease of use of the web app
column25: Privacy features available in the web app
column26: Overall experience of the onboarding flow (where you initially set up your name, timezone, assistant's name, etc.)
column27: Overall experience of the introductory tour
column28: Overall experience of the assistant over email
column31: How human-like does the assistant sound over email? 1 is not human-like at all and 5 is indistinguishable from a human.
column32: How much do you trust the assistant to not make mistakes? 1 is the least trust and 5 is the most.
column33: How many emails did you sent with the assistant in CC? You should send at least one email.
column34: Did the assistant understand your email(s) correctly?
column35: Did the assistant respond to your email in a reasonable amount of time?
column36: Did the assistant meet your expectations in terms of scheduling an appointment?
column37: Which of these features of the web app did you use?
column38: If you were the recipient of an email from EIVA, would you be able to tell whether it's an email from an AI or human assistant, if you didn't know?
column39: If we launch EIVA as a service where users can get their own assistants, will you use it?
column40: Based on the amount of time EIVA saves when setting appointments, how much would you be willing to pay for such a service?
column41: Did you find anything frustrating that you wish was easier or different?
column42: Is there anything that you wish the assistant could do, in terms of scheduling, that it doesn't currently?
column43: What do you like the most about EIVA?
column44: What do you like the least about EIVA?
column45: Do you have any additional feedback, suggestions, or comments?
column46: How accurate, practical, and logical were the time recommendations made by the assistant?
column47: Did the assistant recommend the correct location for the appointment?

column41: Perhaps the introduction could be a bit shorter: it cycles through different settings that I didn't change. For a quick introduction into the application I would prefer to get going fast and be reminded that there are more settings at a later time when I already did my first experiments with scheduling a meeting.
column42: I would like more control over the times used when scheduling meetings: pause times between appointments, preferences for time periods to keep free from appointments as much as possible to improve focus, etc.
column43: It doesn't interfere with my normal workflow: I can still use the tools I always do and it's not necessary for me to log in to the web interface all the time.
column44: It doesn't fully seem to know/understand my reasoning behind picking or proposing certain meeting times, where maintaining focus during my work day plays an important role.
column45: If the assistant would give me the feeling that it understands my scheduling preferences it would be a great addition to my daily workflow.

4. The format of writing date is limited to a few formats, where as people tend to write the date differently and hence the app should understand the date in different formats.
5. "Skip Introduction" should be allowed
